direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody is suddenly pinned under a soggy charred horror; the gory remains of Diane, burnt beyond recognition,: flesh peeled away, discolored, charred, ruined by days in salt water. He screams, and scrabbles in the wet sand, trying to get out of the dreadful clutches of the half-human thing he's dredged from the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Extricating himself, puking, retching, splashing water on his face, washing his hands frantically, just behind him, The Thing lying on the sand, a gruesome joke played by the sea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NIGHT - EXTREME CLOSEUP - CYANIDE BOTTLE Macro close on a pharmaceutical bottle of Sodium Cyanide, from which a syringe is withdrawing a healthy dose. Follow the syringe and reveal Brody, working at his desk in the deserted office. He is injecting the deadly chemical into some jacketed .38 hollow-point ammunition; a dozen cartridges are lined up in neat array, he is filling the last of them, sealing the points with wax from a burning red candle. The radio scanner is monitoring the local police band: routine reports faintly in the b.g. -- a slow night in pre-season Amity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As a sound at the door makes him look up. He hides the odd gear as Hendricks enters, starched and crisp in his uniform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's an awkward pause. Brody sees the box with the divers' stuff sitting where it was left earlier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hendricks' guilty look confirms he didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Deputy rummages in the locker, happy to be on the trail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he runs for the door, the speed-loaders with the Cyanide bullets safely in his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody pats his pockets to make sure the speed-loaders are safe inside, then exits. As Hendricks watches him go,
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I missed you at the funeral home. Santos said you were here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You didn't miss much. Christ, what a mess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The woman passenger on the boat that blew up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That one -- from the wreck. You brought it up, did you look inside it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what the hell -- might be something worth seeing. Take it somewhere and see if there's film in it...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (catching on) If there is, develop it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know just where to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course not, They're closed. Phil Fogarty's place. He'll do it for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The drugstore's closed? What the hell time is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit -- I'm late for dinner... Close up, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (at the door) Oh yeah -- I'm expecting a long distance call, very important. Give them my home phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brody's jeep pulls up, and he gets out, beat. He is slouching towards the door when he hears the phone ring inside. He perks up, and starts to move faster.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen is on the phone in the den as Brody enters the house. The Kids are on the floor in front of the TV, playing an electronic video game that pings and beeps softly under the following.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts upstairs, casually concealing the towel-wrapped package of gun and ammunition.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes upstairs, Ellen waits a few beats, then follows him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (into the phone) Thank you. I'll tell him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hanging up) Sort of -- Matthew Hooper is aboard the research vessel Aurora, presently in the Antarctic Ocean, and won't be in radio range until half-past next spring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brody comes up the stairs and goes into the bedroom, where he carefully puts the gun in the bed table. Ellen finds him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both know what that means -- the morgue. Brody goes into the bathroom and starts scrubbing his hands compulsively.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, perfect -- a 75 per cent family affair. Where were you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ellen follows Brody, watches as he washes under too-hot water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike comes up the stairs, and is starting into his room when Brody spots him; Sean is just behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike shrugs and crosses to his father; Sean whizzes past on into his room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He expects something: this is a formal audience with the Head of The House.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see Sean's door opening as he peeps into the hall to see what the fuss is about.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I said. Is there any of that hand cleaner stuff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Use the little brush there. Why were you at Santos'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Found one of the missing victims from that boat deal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Want to talk about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want to come here a minute?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got something for you to do tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sailing? (Mike nods) Forget it. You're beached. Grounded. No more boats.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No backtalk! I spoke to Upton, at the beach, and he's got a job for you there. You can work until school starts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wanted a job, he's got one. I want to see that boat out of the water by tomorrow night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It opens a few inches, he looks out at the grownups and his brother, decides he wants no part of this, and quietly closes the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Tomorrow night. Out of the water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Mike silently storms into his room, not-so-silently slamming the door as he exits. From inside the room, loud rock music muffled behind the door -- an expression of teen-age rebellion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The music lowers its volume. Brody turns to go into the bedroom, to take his shoes off, to go to bed...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen gets up, and quietly closes the door. The upstairs hallway is empty, the doors closed. The Brody household compartmented and closed for the night.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I know what you're going to say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on the bed) In the city, it happened all the time -- some Kid o.d.'s on a rooftop, top, a drunk gets cut in pieces under the Brooklyn local, old people die alone in shitty apartments and three weeks later someone calls the cops because of the smell and the flies. Call the cops. What are we, immune?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The goddamn smell is always the same. (he shudders at the recollection)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you going to be able to sleep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah. I think so. (he raises his voice) Mike! Keep it down, for chrissake!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The familiar striped cabanas flank the white sands; there's a crowd of midweek seasonal tourists and locals oblivious to the tall steel tower that dominates the beach. A classy van outfitted for passengers pulls into the parking area, followed by Vaughn's Cadillac; the parking attendant waves them into a preferential area, where they disembark: Vaughn, Peterson, Ellen, and some more prospects, including a woman named Bryant and her daughter, Renee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He scoops up a handful of the fine powder. Ellen directs the attention of the photographers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen nods, preoccupied. Vaughn strolls away, headed in the direction of the cabanas. Mary Nichols, a local Selectwoman, emerges from behind the counter of one of the concessions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Michael Brody, dressed in township workman's coveralls, is repainting some flaking woodwork. Sean is happily mixing paint. Vaughn joins them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He continues his chore, without enthusiasm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He points at the tower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He crosses briskly to where Peterson is finishing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Peterson excuses himself and joins the Mayor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is the town beach; the development naturally has its own private access, but I wanted you to see the concession area. Look at that sand -- like sugar!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: During the summer, the sun sets right there... (she points) Over the water. Beautiful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Ellen) I'll say hello for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello -- selling some more of the good life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A piece here, a piece there, it all adds up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your husband's been here all morning. What's he doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know where your dad is?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And if you have any questions about recreational possibilities, Ellen Brody here will be happy to answer them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Len, can I see you a minute?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think we got a couple of live ones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sweeping the water with binoculars, restless eyes trying to scan everything, a grim watchman high over the heads of the unseeing crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry Vaughn, Jr. comes skimming in close to the surf. Bob is handling the sheets, Larry is giving young Jackie sailing lessons -- at the moment he's showing her how the tiller works.  He's on her like glue.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob does, Larry trims the main, and the hull lifts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She snuggles in Larry's arms. He waves to someone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jackie waves without seeing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is fun! Can we go faster?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Vaughn waves back, preoccupied. Near him, Mike Brody looks up, his face grim, jealous, and now a little nuts. He splashes paint onto the wood with angry abandon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Bryant approaches them, tugging her daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At the mention of lunch, the prospects, all hungry, begin flocking back into the van. Peterson herds them along.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (waving) How the hell do we get him down from there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe nobody will notice. Let's get them back in the bus.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . BRYANT Renee wants to know what that man is doing way up there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a precocious little girl) It's a shark tower. I saw one in Florida. He's looking for sharks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's an observation platform. That's our Chief of Police. He's just checking it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Normally, it's used for, ah, bird watching. Nature observation. Weather measurements, that sort of thing. (a little desperate) Ellen, we're running late!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Folks, if we could get back on, we'll show you the country club, and stop for lunch...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The country club has an 18-hole course, putting greens, and twelve tennis courts...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: still scanning. His body suddenly tenses. There's something out there. He mashes his binoculars to his eyes, trying to get a better look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Through the binoculars, something big and black, moving under the buoys and into the swimming area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He can't believe it. But looking past him, we can see it with the unaided eye: a seething dark mass, moving through the water towards the unprotected bathers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one can hear him. A few little faces look up, unable to catch what he's saying. He starts climbing down the ladder shouting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (screaming) Out of the water! Everyone out of the water!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get out of the water! Tell everyone to get out! Now! Out of the water!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: reacting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell is he doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Looking up, startled at Brody's sudden panic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The dark mass almost on top of the swimmers, who are starting to look around. Most of them are oblivious to what's happening on shore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as his feet hit the sand and he starts running for the water, fumbling for his gun and the speed-loader with the cyanide bullets. He is bumping into people, knocking little kids over, stepping on blankets and umbrellas, a madman.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Out of the water! Now! Everyone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Running too, half-stumbling, half-believing, remembering...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Moving after her husband, while Mike steadies Sean, holding the impulsive kid back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gun is out now, he's trying draw a bead on the shape in the water; chest heaving, he tries to steady his shaky grip. People see the gun and scream, throwing themselves flat on the sand, running, some of them going into the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He fires. Again. Bullets ricochet off the water, howling towards the horizon. Real panic now. Four more shots. Reloading, ejected rounds falling bright into the sand, Brody on his knees, fumbling with bullets.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No! Don't go in! Stay out! Stay clear!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: standing on his platform, shocked, watching the Chief of Police fumbling with his gun.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's bluefish! It's a school of bluefish! Chief! It's bluefish!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It is bluefish -- a tight mass of them, churning up the water in a dark, dense group. The swimmers look around, confused by the shots and excitement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughter defuses the tension in the water; bathers move around, some getting closer to see the fish, others leaving the water to join friends and families on the sand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Someone get me a rod and reel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: where Brody is now standing, panting, coming down as a crowd collects at a safe distance around him: Ellen emerges from a group that includes Vaughn, Peterson, and Nichols.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Curious crowd murmurs as they watch this lunacy. Brody realizes he's fired his weapon, that spent shells litter the sand at his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen joins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody drops to his knees, fumbling for the cyanide bullets in his gun, trying to put things in order, scrabbling in the sand for the empty shells. The crowd is curious and embarrassed. Some turn away, others drift back to their blankets, talking about what's just happened, others stare rudely. Brody is coming apart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean emerges from the crowd, and helps his daddy pick up the bullets, Ellen moves to disperse the rudely curious.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, it's all over, go on, it's over. No trouble...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all right, everything's all right...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Let's go, everyone... Mrs. Bryant, Len, please...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He sees Sean, his eyes fill with tears, and he grabs the kid in a fierce hug.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hurriedly called meeting of the town's Selectmen is in session: Vaughn, Peterson, and three others: Kaiser, an old man still in his grocery clerk's apron; Sansom; and Nichols, the woman on the beach.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You should've been out there. You should've seen him waving that gun, like a maniac. There were shots fired!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He thought he had a good reason.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NICHOLS But that's not rational behavior!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NICHOLS Hundred! Literally hundreds. What are they going to say about us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Vaughn) Larry, I'm a businessman, trying to make a buck like anybody else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So it can't be done like that. The man's a menace, plain and simple.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, what am I supposed to do? It's done, it's over. We have to deal with the consequences.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what we're here to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. Let's go into my office, where we can have a little privacy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as the selectmen troop into the cramped quarters. Vaughn deliberately closes the door as they find seats around the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I believe we have a quorum, and informally, I suggest we call this meeting an executive session and dispense with minutes...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brody, alone, is sitting at his desk, morosely studying a little gold statuette of a pistol marksman. What's done is done, and Brody is trying to figure out how to live with it. The phone rings, is answered in the other room. The buzzer sounds. Brody picks up his end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He slams down the phone and gets up to go, suddenly possessed with a purpose.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Polly, no calls, please... (she insists) Okay, okay. (he punches a button) Hello... Phil? Fogarty? What pictures... I'll be right down...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Amid the equipment, clutter and proofs, some shots of the holidome opening, drying on wires. Phil Fogarty, the indignant fat man and town photographer, is locking the door behind an impatient Brody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds out an 8 x 10 proof, Brody snatches it from him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know what you did, but that kid stopped. I haven't heard one peep, not one 'breaker breaker' for days. Believe me, it's a pleasure...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You said something about a camera.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure -- Jeff Hendricks brought in this camera, see, from underwater, and I didn't know how to get it open, but my brother-in-law, in Montauk, he works at a hi-fi store, and they sell cameras, so he...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, yeah, I did, that's the funny thing. You can't tell much from the negatives, I was going to blow 'em up. Here's a test I did...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brody stares down at it. Sure enough, the ghostly outlines of the Orca, underwater, a diver on the deck making a gesture at the camera.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not bad -- that's a real fast lens, probably 1.4. Look at the diffusion, though...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gestures, Brody steps to one side of a table with some big enamel pans for washing and developing prints. Phil switches to a red light, and takes some printing paper, putting it under the enlarger.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's see -- you got a minute?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Phil, don't jerk me around.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Enlarger light going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Timer ticking, the hand turning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quick negative images: water, boat, diver, hand, boat again, tantalizing fragments of the opening sequence projected on the enlarger's flat base.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hypo and Developer sloshing in a pan under Phil's hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody staring down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quietly gaining contrast in a pan of developer, a print of what at first looks like seaweed, then is unmistakably the grinning jaws of the Great White.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - SHARK A quick nightmare vision of Brody, alone in a sinking Orca, trapped in a battered cabin interior; a Great White crashes through the glass, its head huge as it lunges.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PHOTOGRAPH IN DEVELOPER (PROCESS) The close-up detail of this otherwise blurred and unreadable photo is unmistakably a detail from a very close view of the snapping jaws of a Great White; if you hadn't seen it as a memory, it would make no sense at all. For Brody, the meaning is all too clear; for anyone who's never seen the monster face-to-face, it's nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phil's hands, holding plastic tongs, gently slosh the print in the bath. The shark's features are indistinguishable from the surrounding detail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody walks into view, and starts up the steps into the town hall, already lit from within. He's carrying a large envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Selectmen (Kaiser, Sansom, Nichols), Len Peterson, and Vaughn are seated informally around the big table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody enters, carrying the envelope with the photo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He fumbles with the envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He throws the picture down in front of them. They bend over to study it, pass it around, look at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Seaweed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's underwater, isn't it? That's why it's so dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He snatches up the photo.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank God you guys were all together. I got something for you. Proof!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Martin, this is kind of an official meeting
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Chief -- the Board of Selectmen has a question only you can answer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is Jeff Hendricks qualified to fill in as an interim Chief of Police in your absence?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Temporarily? Uh... sure... The question's out of left field. Why are they asking?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So Jeff could handle things? He knows the routine, he has the authority?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It came up during the meeting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look -- I just got this from Phil Fogarty. It was in the camera belonging to the missing divers. It proves I was right, all along.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know -- what is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a shark! A Great White! Jesus, it's right there!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: PHOTO Just as before, an ambiguous pattern of light and dark; not proof of anything without Brody's inner vision.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: waving the picture.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sansom and Kaiser agree, ad lib, "That's nothing..."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Selectmen look at each other in the face of Brody's agitation. Tempers are running high.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Selectmen file into Vaughn's office, leaving Brody alone in the room. The last one in the door very carefully makes sure it's tightly shut. Brody sits alone at the table.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you all, blind? It's a shark. Look -- teeth, jaw, gills.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're damn right that's what it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, I just don't see it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exploding) What the hell does it take to make sense to you numbskulls? Jesus, it's right there in front of you. I know what a goddamn shark looks like, I've been through it, don't you understand? I've seen this sonofabitch before!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What have you seen before? This is nothing. Seaweed. Mud. Something in the lens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Vaughn) Forget it, he won't listen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blowing up) Will you listen to this man? Will you just listen to him? (to Brody) You really caused a panic on a public beach, you shoot up the place, God knows who could've been injured -- what if somebody decides to sue us? That could ruin us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that what it is? Dollars? Money? I'll pay for it. Take it out of my salary.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I don't make as much money as some bullshit rip-off artists around here, but I don't work the same way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It means I don't like all that grab- ass and heavy breathing with my wife, it means I know who's out to screw me here, and it means that I know something none of you know because I've been there -- and I don't want to go through that horror again. Ever!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Martin, could you wait here for a few minutes while we make up our minds about something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They are sitting there, deliberating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the hands go up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn's hand goes up, the sole dissent. They stare at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to the door, and opens it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I won't mention his personal attack on me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never seen him like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And Hendricks is qualified, you heard that from his own mouth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We made a motion and it was already seconded.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (official) Very well then. It is moved and seconded that Martin Brody be relieved of his duties as Chief of Police, his contract with the township be terminated, and that Jeff Hendricks be appointed Acting Chief in the interim. Those in favor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone opposed, or is it unanimous?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, but I respect his convictions. The motion is carried.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Martin? Could you come in please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The police jeep pulls up and stops; although the engine's shut down, Brody still sits quietly inside the car. Then his hand appears at the window, and he drops an empty beer can onto the lawn. Clink. After a while, he drops another beer can, then another, until the "clinks" tell us he's polished off a six-pack on the way home. Not too steady on his feet, Brody climbs out of the car and starts for the door to his house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen is working at her desk in the den. She is looking towards the door, expectantly -- it's been an unusually long pause between car arrival and husband arrival. Brody enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a long look at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes to join her, bumping into some furniture in the dimly lit room. Ellen has a beer and sandwich half-finished on her desk; Brody takes a healthy swallow from the beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He tosses the photo sloppily on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody's slipping under; the beers and the day have finally overcome him. He slumps in Ellen's arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She eases him onto the couch, tucking a comforter over his inert shape.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi. I closed a sale today, without Len. That's $1200 commission, if the papers go through.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You look about 22 years old sitting there. Like you were doing homework...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ooohh, nothing. I just got fired, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then that's what I meant. Fired. Canned. Out on my fanny. The Selectmen just made Hendricks the new Chief of Police. Just like that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (expansively) No sweat. A blessing in disguise. Back to the city, you can go to Bloomingdale's without waiting six hours for the ferryboat... we're surrounded by water here, you realize that? Me, surrounded by water... Ridiculous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop that! We're not going any place. You love it here. Tell me what the hell happened!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Showed them the photo, showed them the goddamn Shark, big as life. They didn't see it. Not like me. Not like the poor son-of-a-bitch who snapped this li'l picture... He's out there, somewhere... I shot off my gun, shot off my big mouth, so they fired me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (studying the photo) Honey, this is nothing... I don't know what it is. What did they...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (going on) ...Everybody wants the job. No one wants the authority. Except Hendricks. Fine. He can go out there in that precious boat, and when he looks whitey in his big mouth he can just call me. Call me in New York... tell him to kiss my ass...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (seeing his pain) They have no right to treat you like that. You've given them everything. For four years, you've protected this town, the people on this island...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fired me! (at Ellen) I'm not a hysterical man. I'm responsible. I know what I saw...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I try. Goddamnit, I tried... Now, I'm tired... I can't keep fighting it... I'm too tired... I'm... I'm...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're drunk is what you are...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sean comes down the stairs, sleepy, in his pajamas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He comes into the darkened den.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is dad home? I heard something...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Shhhh. Go back upstairs. Daddy's sleeping. Sean finds the photo, and stares at it idly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes him by his sleepy hand and leads him out of the room, leaving Brody tucked in on the couch, dead to the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the Amity teen-ager's hangout -- a newsstand and pinball arcade with a minimal refreshment counter where soft drinks and submarine sandwiches are dispensed. A jukebox is blaring some n.d. rock music. Present are Donnie, Doug, Timmy, Bob, Larry Vaughn Jr., Brooke, Marge, Denise, Jane, Andy, and Mike. The boys are passing around hot-rod van and custom boat magazines; the girls are looking at Silver Screen, Tiger Beat, People, and Time. Andy and Mike are at the counter, splitting a sandwich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one does. There's a bustle at the door, and some couples enter from the movies: Patrick and Lucy, Ed and Tina, Polo and Jackie. There are a lot of ad-lib greetings;
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a general ad-lib agreement to organize a day's sailing picnic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Laughter from the gang.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They break up into pairs and trios, some going for the soda fountain, others hanging out by the magazines.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (holding a book) That's what I want -- a gaff rig.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gaff rigged? Why not a staysail schooner? Go anywhere. Look at this -- the Mayan, an Alden schooner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Mike -- I saw your dad over at the town hall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (innocently) Did he really freak out at the beach?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, it's all bullshit. Anyone want to play pong for money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone want to go the lighthouse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nah. Tomorrow. Early, spend the day. My folks left two cases of beer in the garage.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope. Got it in my boat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you might still be painting the restrooms at the beach.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone want a coke or anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: I'd like to go out to the lighthouse with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They ad lib agreement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brooke takes Mike aside, as Jackie goes to the jukebox. Larry is right there with a quarter, standing next to her as they select a tune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some rock music starts, and we:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you and Brooke could come over to the town beach...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No way. Everybody's going sailing. If you don't want to take me, just say so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not it. My dad told me not to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You do everything your parents tell you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. I'll be on the dock at eight. (to the gang) Eight o'clock, everybody!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (aside to Mike) I really want to to be there. (to the crowd) Who's bringing the wine? And who's got a quarter for the box?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She just likes to tease. I think she really likes you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ellen is asleep under the covers, Brody, still in his clothes from the night before, is sprawled on top; obviously he's stumbled upstairs sometime during the night. There's a noise down the hall, from Mike's room. Brody stirs, but doesn't wake up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike is holding a lamp that's almost fallen -- the noise we just heard. He's almost dressed, but not quite satisfied with his image in the mirror. He takes off his clean shirt, and checks a more comfortable, worn shirt. A brief sniff to make sure it's okay for another day, and he puts it on; he tiptoes to the hall, where a noise stops him in his tracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike is frozen in his part-opened bedroom door. Sean's door opens, and little Sean, also fully dressed, comes sneaking out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean does, and happily tiptoes with exaggerated stealth to Mike; the two of them start downstairs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (louder) I want to go with you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Michael and Sean are walking away towards the road into town.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody emerges from the bathroom, dressed in sweatshirt, and cutoffs: no uniform today. He starts downstairs, stopping only to look into Mike's room. It's empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A grin crosses his face -- "My son, the Don Juan..." He goes downstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody enters from upstairs. He heats coffee. Ellen enters dressed for work. He pours two cups.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pours the coffee, they drink it for a moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen and Brody sip their coffee quietly for a few moments. Mrs. Silvera arrives, carrying groceries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean's not up yet. You know what he likes, just some Fruit Loops and milk. No candy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sink upstairs is busted. Try some Drano, or a plunger, maybe. Or call your brother, the plumber, what's his name...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody and Ellen are at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They leave.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What're you going to do today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turn in the car. Clean my desk, explain things to our sons, then maybe get shit-faced and punch your boss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't rush into it -- we may need the income.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mike left early. Couldn't wait to make out. Must be a morning man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Frankie. Okay. Ask him if he needs an apprentice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Kids are into their boats, fitting out for a day of recreational offshore sailing. Mike and Andy are readying his Tornado, while Sean gets in the way. In the b.g., Hendricks can be seen puttering around on the Amity police boat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sean knocks something over, Mike snaps at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marge joins them, scooping Sean up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marge and Sean go over to her Lightening. Brooke and Jackie come down the dock, dressed for sailing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike looks: Andy, Jackie, Brooke, himself... Timmy moves in, sensing the chance of a lifetime.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Timmy makes his move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she walks towards his boat, looking back for him to follow. He's dumbstruck by his sudden good fortune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs to join her, untying mooring lines like crazy; they're together again at last for the first time. Andy is left shuffling with Mike and Jackie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she plops down in Mike's boat, ready to be taken. Anywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jackie flashes him one of her pouty little smiles. Why break one heart when you can break two? Or more?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike is glaring. The message is clear, if unspoken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andy joins them.  Mike casts off, while Andy helps, and Jackie sits there, looking cute.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If you're beached, why are we doing this? For practice?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why are we futzing around the dock? We can make a few bucks working at the beach.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look -- if you're going to get in the way, you can just go home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not in the way. Andy, am I in the way?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This guy giving you any trouble?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Put him down in the water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Sean) You want to go out in my boat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've just made someone very happy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can go out if I want to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I could give you a dozen good reasons.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, okay, don't say I didn't remind you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is there room on your boat for all of us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we're pretty crowded, and I don't know when we're leaving...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great. (to Andy) That's okay -- I'll go with Timmy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: watching what's going on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bob gets the message and shuts up. The Sizzler fills its sails, and points out of the harbor.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you said she was going with us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (casting off) Want to talk about it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Lots of day-sailing Kids, a few bigger, adult boats, some working fishermen and sport fishers; a typical recreational boating mix. The Kids are finding the same general direction, pointing out of the harbor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- Sails being trimmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brooke and Timmy, staring into each other's eyes as he sets a course straight for the lighthouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry, lifting a hull, almost losing Bob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Kids' boats, in a loose bunch, slipping out to sea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - LOOKING OUT TO SEA The dive class boat, isolated near the channel, a group of Kids in wet suits and tanks assembled with three adult instructors: Tom Andrews, Crosby, and Sparky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andrews and his assistant instructor, Sparky, are addressing the class, when Mike and Andy's "Green Machine" sails by, close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andrews dismisses them with a good-natured wave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns to his class.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The class dutifully lines up and starts going in, while in the b.g. the Kids sailboats head out to sea. Andrews' two partners, Crosby and Sparky, get ready to follow the class over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes over, Andrews following. Sparky is with the class, signaling "Down;" they submerge like clumsy seals.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! Nicholas! You're supposed to be in class!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Today I'm staying topside. You dive for me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With butter, if they got any...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sparky will take you down today. If everyone's got a buddy, we'll drop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The class, paired up, is drifting down; Sparky offering encouragement as they descend. Andrews and Crosby are already disappearing, swimming away with strong kicks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as they go over the edge of a shelf and drop into darker, deeper waters. Crosby checks his depth, his watch, looks around...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: far above him, the class, going about their business. Below him, murk, depth, and suddenly, a big lunker bass. Andrews sees it, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Assuming Crosby is following, he takes off, following the big lunker. Crosby, hung up in some minor equipment problem, misses seeing him go. The two men are separated. Follow Andrews as he twists and turns after the bass, going deeper, losing him in the rocks, suddenly rounding a boulder, and meeting, almost face-to-face, horror:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Great White Shark, taking the striper in a single gulp, it's looking up at Andrews with one glassy doll's eye; it turns to face him directly, and we see the scar; ugly, red and black, charred flesh from jaw back on the right side, eyes and teeth gleaming like raw bone in the massive, uncaring face. Andrews' mouth clamps violently on his mouthpiece, then goes wide as he screams in fear into the water. Finning backwards, he ditches his weights, gulps for air, and yanks the cord on his safety vest. It balloons out, and pulls him up, surging towards the surface. The mouthpiece, useless, falls away from his lips. Eyes closed, hose dangling, Andrews hurtles upward, holding his breath in a final, fatal panic, passing a startled Crosby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: look over at the rocketing ascent. What's wrong? Sparky signals "up," and they begin to carefully follow him towards the surface. Crosby's already surfacing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andrews is on his side, bloody froth on his lips. One of the class is clinging to his legs, trying to arrest his convulsions. Sparky is holding his shoulders, trying to administer mouth-to-mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In his arms, Andrews writhes, pain knotting his limbs. Behind them, in the water, the fin surfaces, and casually turns towards... the ocean. The Shark is headed for the sea. And for the now distant Kids in their sailboats, dotting the horizon in their familiar bright colors.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get us in! For Christ's sake, get us in!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They are alone. In the middle distance, the rest of the Kids' sails can be seen, headed for the lighthouse in the distance. The Sandpiper's sails are luffing, they're making no headway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed is lashing the rudder as they continue to drift with the current.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He fumbles in a cooler chest, produces a bottle of wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pours the wine into the two paper cups.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And he fumbles for a blanket in a locker, thumping and banging gear around as he rummages for it. Tina sips wine contentedly, satisfied to wait.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You want to tack, or just leave her pointed up like this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The tide's running. It'll take us to the light.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It'll take us to Budapest if you're not careful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They'll be there when we get there. Might even have a fire started.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What're we going to do in the mean time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I dunno. We'll think of something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (resisting) Wait a minute. Promise me something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That you'll put down a blanket. I've got black and blue marks all over my butt, and my Mom's getting uptight about them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Sandpiper's hull, alone above us, as the Shark rises with dreadful certainty, attracted by the erratic sounds of Ed's hasty search.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - WATCHING THE OCEAN The terrible fin breaks the surface, about 20 yards out, then dips and disappears. Then, impossibly fast, the entire Sandpiper is lifted from underneath by a powerful surge, as the Shark lunges up against it from below, an unseen horror. Ed is knocked over the side, into the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as he breaks the surface, shaking the hair out of his eyes, trying to orient himself, finding the boat. He starts to swim for it, Tina extending an arm to help him climb aboard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He has barely taken two strokes when a powerful force takes him from below the surface, rushing him towards us through the water. Tina screams. Before Ed can react to the pain, he is slammed face first into the boat. His jaw breaks, blood smears his nose and lip. His hands grab the wooden-cap rail with a death-grip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tina is staring down at the water, terror-stricken; Ed's arms and head are f.g., as he locks onto the boat with desperate hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ed's hands on the rail, knuckles white, an iron grip. With awful finality, the force pulls down, and the wood shatters and splits away as Ed's hands are pulled down and under by the awful force.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: her mouth working silently, unable to scream, staring down at the blood and froth on the water, swirling in a grim eddy under her, the Sandpiper rocking gently in the diminishing swell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: DAY - ESTABLISHING SHOT On the way to the lighthouse, but away from the harbor, the Kids are sailing in fairly close order: The sloops (Polo, Timmy, Marge) heeled well over in the stiff breeze, the faster cats (Mike, Larry, Donny, etc.) skimming around, tacking more often, faster and more maneuverable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Faster! Faster!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She ducks under the boom, handling the jib sheets with easy familiarity. They come about and scoot off on a new tack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reading the wind, trimming sail expertly, competent and alone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to a near-by boat) Great day! I think the wind's going to change...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He comes about, she slides into him, he holds her to steady her, she snuggles into his arms. True love, at last... He's thrilled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In his inflatable, poking slowly along. Marge passes him, Sean hooting with glee.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm getting new sails, then watch out. Just a question of modifying the rigging!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Jackie, Mike and Andy, clipping along, Larry Vaughn and Bob in the Sizzler nearby. Mike lifts the hull, Jackie squeals in delight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He trims his sheets, the cat heels more, one hull flying, Andy and Jackie clinging to the trampoline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Larry is carefully adjusting his tiller, Bob senses what he's doing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They gybe sharply, running up behind the green cat.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Like hell! We're on the starboard tack!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Running close to each other; very tight two-by-two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mike and Larry silently fight for clean air, racing. Water splashes over them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He veers onto a less dramatic tack, sparing Jackie's hair. Larry and Bob speed by, yelling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andy reveals a knowledgeable side to his character.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jackie snuggles against Mike.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He goes forward to trim the jib, leaving the lovebirds snuggling astern. They pull away from us, and we:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When do we get to the lighthouse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're going to be fighting the current. (he looks up) Wind's backing around a few points, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't wait to get there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ellen and Brody are in the jeep; he's driving her to work. There's a crowd at dockside, and the town ambulance's now familiar blinking red light. Brody, out of force of habit, wheels the jeep towards the action, nudging through the crowd, which gives way to the official blue-and-white vehicle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gets out, and pushes through the crowd, Ellen following.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey -- it's not your job any more. I'm going to be late for work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The dive boat is moored at a clumsy angle next to the Police Boat, where Hendricks has been pulling routine maintenance. The Police launch is cluttered with tools and spare parts; some non-essential piece of gear is stripped and laid out on the deck. Hendricks is on the dive boat, kneeling next to Andrews.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Andrews is shaking, bloody froth on his lips and chest. The shaken divers are huddled together, an ambulance attendant is wheeling a gurney into position. Crosby and Sparky are stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is near collapse himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An Ambulance Attendant is putting a blanket around Sparky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The other attendant holds something out to Brody. Brody examines it; a scuba mouthpiece, bitten in two, useless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody is gone, pushing through the crowd.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Embolism. Air bubbles in his blood. Came up too damn fast. Held his goddamn breath!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's okay. We're taking care of him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right after, the Kids went out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All of them. Mike, Junior Vaughn, Brookie Peters, Pat, Lucy -- all that whole gang.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yep. Looked like they were headed to the lighthouse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About an hour, maybe two. (thinking) Let's see -- I came on about eight...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brody is casting off lines. Ellen is on the dock, watching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody keeps working, making ready for sea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ellen is climbing aboard, taking off her heels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody starts the engines with a roar, and slams it into reverse. The boat starts out of the slip, then lunges to a halt, shuddering on its still-fastened bow mooring line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she moves purposefully towards the boat cleat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody is shifting gears, the boat is crabbing sideways as he puts the helm hard over. It bumps the dock, hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hendricks goes to the bow, jumps aboard and frees the bow line. The boat slips into reverse, the water boiling as Brody guns it away from the dock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes the wheel, eases off on the rudder, and comes about, pointing the launch out to sea.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Uh, Chief -- look. You're not Chief any more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't let you take her out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Brody, look -- if he can't go, then you can't go. Neither of you can go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I signed for the boat. You're not authorized any more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamnit, Hendricks, untie the rope there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What the hell, they can't fire both of us -- someone's got to be in charge, right? Which way are we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Find the Kids. The lighthouse -- you said something about the lighthouse. Get us there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Amity Police Boat, Brody, Ellen and Hendricks aboard, is headed under full power out to sea. Hendricks is pumping the horn, warning boats out of the way, ignoring the rules of the road; as small boats scatter out of the way, we can see the ambulance, red light flashing, pushing out slowly through the crowd at dockside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As they clear the harbor mouth, Brody is on the radio, Ellen is crouching in the shelter of the deckhouse, Hendricks is steering.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Brody's eyes sweep the horizon anxiously, Hendricks pours it on, and the police boat surges forward.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Amity Launch to Harbor Patrol, over.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) (filtered) Harbor Patrol. Is that you, Brody?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Affirmative. Can you get your chopper airborne?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: in a few minutes. He's down checking a buoy in the Bay Channel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get him the hell over to Amity Point, the old lighthouse. Right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the Pilot overtakes her -- a moment of horror, as she thinks the Shark has found her, then relief, as the Pilot motions to the bubble, and indicates "Air." She follows him.

direction.raw_text: Scuttling like two crabs into the shelter of the broken chopper, buddy breathing as he passes her the oxygen tube. The chopper tilts, and moves, breaking up on the bottom as currents move it. They struggle silently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as it slips across the bottom, the current pulling it, broken parts breaking off in slow motion, dirty swirls of oil and hydraulic fluid clouding the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THE RAFT A parallel struggle for survival, as the current separates Sean from the other Kids; Marge is gone, the little boy is clinging alone to the free-floating Lightening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - A DISTANCE AWAY Copter wreckage is bubbling up from underneath, like a submarine destroyed by depth charges; an oil slick, pieces of broken blade, a seat cushion, then, suddenly, the Pilot, and Marge, almost choked to death, their air run out. They cling to a section of pontoon, panting, looking around with oxygen-starved eyes. They are alone on the ocean; a half-mile away, the distant sails of the broken raft, and the low-lying shape of Cable Junction. Safe, for now...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The familiar voice is tinged with annoyance. He's had a long shift, and nothing's going right.

direction.raw_text: Brody revs up, and powers out, headed for Cable Junction.

direction.raw_text: DAY - THE RAFT Sean is crying on his isolated perch, clinging to the upturned keel. The other Kids are throwing a rope, trying to get him back. Patrick heaves, and misses.

direction.raw_text: The others shoot fearful glances at the waters.

direction.raw_text: He scrambles out, hardly wet, that's how fast he's moving. Finally -- Patrick takes the crucial throw, and the rope practically knocks Sean off his perch, but he clutches and holds it. As Andy carefully calls instructions, Sean secures the rope and the others carefully, carefully begin to pull him in.

dialogue.raw_text: He's got to help or it won't work.

direction.raw_text: looking over the wreckage to Cable Junction, now much closer. Beyond it, miles of empty Atlantic. It's off to one side, and unless they can slow down or alter course, they will miss it.

dialogue.raw_text: By 7:46, when the tide turns around, we'll be twenty miles out. More, with this wind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (praying aloud) God, please help us, Merciful Father, in Christ's name, we beg you, help us, please, Dear God, save us, help us, please, God, help...

direction.raw_text: DAY - THE RAFT approaching Cable Junction the rafted boats are drifting towards the Cable Junction.  Larry, Patrick and Andy are working on improvised tiller lines to a jury rudder made out of wreckage. Lucy has another line out to a sea anchor, trying to slow their drift.

direction.raw_text: - THE RAFT Brady catches the Kids' line. He heaves on it with all his might. Nothing. Jackie is hysterical, some of the other Kids are screaming. The Shark's fin catches the taut line, it slides up and over, Brody and the Kids are nearly pulled into the water. The raft doesn't budge.

direction.raw_text: - BRODY AND THE KIDS He sees the winch and hooks on his launch, and makes the towline fast to the steel winch cable; puts it in neutral. The Kids haul their line, trying to bring the steel cable to them. The shark rams their raft, impatient now. Screams and scrambling as they let go their line and try to avoid the beast. Brooke huddles with Sean, Jackie cowers alone. Larry is lashing his big buck knife to a pole, an improvised weapon.

direction.raw_text: paddling the raft towards Sean with desperate strokes, heedless of the danger around him.

direction.raw_text: He fights to see in the gathering gloom. Suddenly, a strange glare snaps on, then more illumination, in a series of escalating clicks.

direction.raw_text: Silhouetted against the evening sky. Automatic timers are turning on navigation and worklights, illuminating the barren rocks and rusty steel with their glare -- throwing dark shadows, putting the surrounding water into black limbo by their contract.

direction.raw_text: straining to see what's going on. Looking for his son.

direction.raw_text: soaked, clinging to the rail of the launch, hearing Brody, fumbling in the cabin, turning on worklights, the boat throwing erratic shafts of powerful light from its many lamps and searchlights. Andy grabs one and sweeps the water with it, trying to help.

direction.raw_text: His light pokes and sweeps through the gloom.

direction.raw_text: He hears the horrendous sounds of wood and metal breaking, as the raft pounds to pieces on the rocks. He is blinded by the sweeping searchlight, the confusion of terror-stricken teen-agers screaming. It's the middle of The Inferno.

direction.raw_text: lunges at the raft, Brody sliding desperately away, smashing at the snout with his steel, the tail fin bashing him as it passes...

direction.raw_text: Brody is drifting close to the cable, drawn heavy and wet cut of the water. He reaches up to it.

direction.raw_text: dangling his feet in the water, holding onto the cable, seeing it, inspired with a lunatic idea...

dialogue.raw_text: Over here! You bastard! Over here
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: turns, bleeding from a superficial cut on its snout, its scar glistening wet and terrible. It heads for Brody.

dialogue.raw_text: Come and get me! Come and get me!

direction.raw_text: Attacking. Missing Brody, who hauls himself up out of the way in life-or-death spasm. The great jaws close, fastening onto the thick cable. Shaking it. The cable resists for a moment, then splits, layers or insulation and armor crack open, the jaws clamp harder -- 20,000 tons of pressure -- then the live copper core is reached. Zap!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: dying. Leaping and convulsing as hundreds of thousands of volts surge through its body, grounded in the salt sea. Hot white fire shimmers like a halo, the fish smokes and stinks, sputters, and dies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watching, cowering on the rubber raft to which he fell when the shark hit the cable. It's strangely silent. The lights on Cable Junction flicker and die as circuit breakers shut down the mains, protecting the line. Only the boat's worklights provide light now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer. Water lapping at the rocks, some Kids sobbing quietly. Brody listlessly paddles towards the wreckage of the raft, expecting the worst...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Timmy's Doughdish, where we last saw Sean. There's a scrabbling from inside, and Sean appears, soaked, from under the seat where he'd fallen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brody moves toward him, holds out his arms, taking Sean onto his raft. They paddle back towards the rocks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with the Kids clinging like drowned rats to the rocks; they're wet, scared, exhausted, but safe. Sean hugs his daddy as they step onto land.

dialogue.raw_text: They made me go with them.

direction.raw_text: A crowd of worried parents and adults, Ellen and Hendricks in the forefront, are staring towards the harbor mouth. It's dawn and the sun is rising. They see something, a cheer goes up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A big Coast Guard cutter is steaming into the harbor, a little group of survivors on the foredeck.

direction.raw_text: Brody and the surviving Kids wave to their families on land.
